questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache and left-sided weakness and numbness for the past 2 hours. She has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, insulin, and warfarin. She is oriented to person, place, and date. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.3°F), pulse is 90/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/94 mm Hg. Examination shows leftward and downward deviation of the eyes. The pupils are miotic and nonreactive. Muscle strength is 2/5 on the left side and 5/5 on the right side. Deep tendon reflexes are decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased on the left side and normal on the right side and the face. Prothrombin time is 51 seconds (INR = 4.3). Hemorrhage into which of the following locations is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar hemorrhage typically manifests with ataxia, dysarthria, facial palsy, and skew deviation of the eyes. Signs of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, neck stiffness) occur early. Hemiparesis, which this patient presents with, is characteristically absent in cerebellar strokes, indicating that another area of her brain is likely affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Putaminal hemorrhage (from anterolateral central arteries) typically manifests with contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemisensory defects, and contralateral gaze palsy with an ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. Therefore, a right-sided putaminal hemorrhage can manifest with left-sided hemiplegia and hemisensory loss. However, a left-sided gaze palsy with a rightward deviation of the eyes would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Pontine hemorrhage typically manifests with quadriplegia, facial paralysis, deafness, and dysarthria. Furthermore, miotic pupils are a feature of pontine stroke. However, affected individuals have ipsilateral horizontal conjugate palsy (i.e., an inability to horizontally look toward the side of the lesion) or, in bilateral pontine hemorrhage, ocular bobbing. Vertical eye movements and blinking are preserved in ventral pontine stroke, a condition known as locked-in syndrome. This patient has almost none of the typical features of pontine hemorrhage.


D) INCORRECT:

Putaminal hemorrhage typically manifests with contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemisensory loss, and contralateral gaze palsy with ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. A left-sided putaminal hemorrhage can manifest with leftward deviation of the eyes. However, right-sided hemiplegia and hemisensory loss would also be expected.

E) CORRECT:

The combination of hemiparesis, hemisensory deficits, miotic and nonreactive pupils, and gaze deviation downward and toward the affected side of the body (i.e., away from the side of the brain lesion) is a phenomenon known as “wrong way eyes” and characteristically occurs in thalamic hemorrhage. In contrast, other sites of supratentorial hemorrhage typically cause a gaze deviation toward the side of the lesion (i.e., away from the affected side of the body). This patient’s left-sided weakness and sensory loss, miotic nonreactive pupils, and leftward and downward deviation of her eyes are best explained by a stroke in the right thalamus.

Note that the thalamus is a relatively large region of the brain and thalamic stroke has a variety of manifestations (e.g., pure sensory stroke in lacunar syndromes). However, “wrong way eyes” is a classical finding of thalamic hemorrhage.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of an older adult

Hyperdense hemorrhage (blue overlay) involving the right thalamus extends to the posterior limb of the right internal capsule. Intraventricular hemorrhage (yellow overlay) is also present. Mass-effect has caused a slight midline shift.

Prominent sulci and ventricles are consistent with cerebral atrophy.

Green overlay: internal capsule; red line: midline; T: thalamus

F) INCORRECT:

A frontal lobe hemorrhage typically manifests with weakness or paralysis of the contralateral leg (sparing the arm) and deviation of the eyes toward the side of the lesion. Although a hemorrhagic stroke in the left frontal lobe can manifest with a leftward deviation of the eyes, right-sided weakness of the lower limb would also be present. In addition, sensation is typically preserved in frontal lobe lesions. Thus, another area of the brain is more likely to be affected in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

A frontal lobe hemorrhage typically manifests with weakness or paralysis of the contralateral leg (sparing the arm) and deviation of the eyes toward the side of the lesion. Sensation is typically preserved in frontal lobe lesions. A right frontal lobe hemorrhage would manifest with weakness in the left leg but also with rightward deviation of the eyes, whereas this patient's eyes deviate leftward.

H) INCORRECT:

Thalamic hemorrhage typically manifests with contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, miotic and unreactive pupils, and upgaze palsy with gaze deviation away from the side of the lesion, a phenomenon known as “wrong way eyes”. A hemorrhagic lesion in the left thalamus would manifest with right-sided weakness and sensory loss with rightward gaze deviation, unlike what is seen in this case.
questions.hint: Hemorrhage in this region may extend into the third ventricle.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of excessive sleepiness. He reports that he has been sleeping for an average of 10 to 12 hours at night and needs to take multiple naps during the day. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with small cell lung carcinoma and underwent prophylactic cranial irradiation. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The preoptic nucleus is located in the anterior hypothalamus and is responsible for thermoregulation and the release of GnRH. Dysregulation of GnRH in males would cause changes in sexual behavior and erectile dysfunction but would not cause sleep disturbances.

B) INCORRECT:

The ventromedial nucleus located in the hypothalamus is responsible for satiety and is stimulated by leptin. Damage or lesions to this region can cause hyperphagia and obesity but would not cause sleep disturbances.

C) CORRECT:

The suprachiasmatic nucleus lies in the hypothalamus and plays an important role in the circadian rhythm pathway. It receives input (light) from the retina. When there is decreased input, the suprachiasmatic nucleus releases norepinephrine, which stimulates the release of sleep-inducing melatonin from the pineal gland. Damage to this pathway (e.g., due to metastasis or radiation) can cause hypersomnolence or sleep-wake disturbances.

D) INCORRECT:

The supraoptic nucleus in the hypothalamus primarily synthesizes ADH (released by the posterior pituitary). Disruption or damage to the supraoptic nucleus would, therefore, decrease levels of ADH and lead to diuresis (i.e., central diabetes insipidus), but it would not cause hypersomnia.

E) INCORRECT:

The caudate nucleus in the basal ganglia is primarily associated with motor function. Damage to this region is associated with psychomotor disease, e.g., Huntington disease. Although the caudate nucleus contributes to the sleep cycle, the absence of motor dysfunction in this patient suggests damage to another neurological structure.

F) INCORRECT:

The subthalamic nucleus is involved in both the direct and indirect motor pathways within the basal ganglia. Lesions in this region are associated with motor dysregulations such as contralateral hemiballismus, or tremor in Parkinson disease. Damage to the subthalamic nucleus is not associated with sleep disturbances.
questions.hint: This structure is responsible for the central regulation of the circadian rhythm.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with hypertension comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of a severe headache 2 hours ago. Her temperature is 34.7°C (94.5°F) and blood pressure is 189/115 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cold skin. A CT scan of the head shows a subarachnoid hemorrhage and she is started on appropriate pharmacotherapy. Damage to which of the following regions of the brain is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anterior cingulate gyrus is involved in modulation of emotional responses and autonomic activity (e.g., heart rate, blood pressure). Damage to the anterior cingulate gyrus would not cause the dysfunctional thermoregulation seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

The ventral lateral nucleus of the thalamus is involved in the coordination of movements. Damage to the ventral lateral nucleus of the thalamus would not cause the dysfunctional thermoregulation seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The pineal gland secretes melatonin, which helps maintain circadian rhythm, including the circadian variation in temperature (i.e., lower nocturnal core body temperatures). Damage to the pineal gland would be more likely to cause a lack of circadian variation in temperature than the more straight-forward hypothermia seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The preoptic nucleus in the anterior hypothalamus is the body's primary thermoregulator. It receives afferent impulses from thermoreceptors in the skin and, in turn, modulates the activity of the organs involved in thermal regulation (e.g., heart, blood vessels) to maintain a normal core body temperature. Other regions of the hypothalamus assist in thermoregulation: The anterior hypothalamic nucleus controls the cooling response (e.g., vasodilation, sweating), while the posterior hypothalamic nucleus controls the warming response (e.g., vasoconstriction, shivering). Damage to the preoptic nucleus can result in either hypothermia or hyperthermia. Circulating pyrogens can also influence the preoptic nucleus to increase the thermoregulatory set point and initiate fever.

In addition to temperature regulation, the preoptic nucleus secretes GnRH (dysfunctional in Kallmann syndrome) and is involved in the regulation of sexual behavior.

E) INCORRECT:

The caudate nucleus plays a role in the coordination of movement and higher cognitive function. Damage to the caudate nucleus is seen in conditions such as Huntington disease but would not cause dysfunctional thermoregulation.
questions.hint: This woman has signs of hypothermia. Although primary hypothermia is caused by environmental exposure to cold, hypothermia can also occur secondary to metabolic derangements, infections, endocrine dysfunction, or lesions of the central nervous system. The latter has likely occurred in this case as a complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the function of the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus in an experimental animal. Using a viral vector, the genes encoding chloride-conducting channelrhodopsins are injected into this nucleus. Photostimulation of the channels causes complete inhibition of action potential generation. Persistent photostimulation is most likely to result in which of the following abnormalities in these animals?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus would not cause hypothermia since this region does not play a role in regulating temperature. Instead, hypothermia is caused by inhibition or destruction of the posterior nucleus, which regulates the conservation of heat via the sympathetic nervous system.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus would not cause hyperthermia since this region does not play a role in regulating temperature. Instead, hyperthermia is caused by inhibition or destruction of the anterior nucleus, which regulates the dissipation of heat via the parasympathetic nervous system.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus would not cause polydipsia since this region does not play a role in water balance. Instead, both the paraventricular nucleus and supraoptic nucleus regulate water balance via ADH. Dysfunction of these regions can result in diabetes insipidus, which causes polydipsia, polyuria, and nocturia.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus would not cause nocturnal hyperactivity since this region does not play a role in circadian rhythm. Instead, the suprachiasmatic nucleus regulates circadian rhythm. Dysfunction of this region can result in sleep disorders (e.g., insomnia, nighttime hyperactivity).

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus would not cause hyperphagia since this region does not play a role in regulating satiety. Instead, the ventromedial nucleus regulates satiety and is stimulated by leptin. Inhibition of action potential generation or destruction of this region can result in hyperphagia and obesity.

F) CORRECT:

The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus regulates hunger. Inhibition of action potential generation or destruction of this region can result in anorexia, starvation, and failure to thrive. Hypothalamic dysfunction plays a role in many conditions, including Prader-Willi syndrome (which manifests with hyperphagia) and anorexia nervosa (which manifests with reduced caloric intake).
questions.hint: The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus is stimulated by ghrelin and inhibited by leptin.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset right-sided body numbness for 1 hour. He reports that he has a 15-year history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He is right-handed. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation to light pinprick and temperature on the right side of the face and body. Motor strength is 5/5 and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Perfusion of which of the following structures of the brain is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of one of its blood-supplying vessels, predominantly the anterior cerebral artery (ACA), and middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of the ACA or MCA may result in numbness. However, a stroke typically on the nondominant (usually right) side would manifest with symptoms of contralateral (left-sided) neglect, while infarction of the dominant (usually left) side would manifest with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia, none of which are present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule occurs due to hemorrhage or occlusion of the lenticulostriate arteries, which supply blood to the greater part of the internal capsule. As fibers of the corticospinal tract pass downward through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, infarction of the posterior limb usually leads to a pure motor stroke with hemiparesis of the leg, arm, and face contralateral to the site of the lesion. Rarely, ischemia of the posterior limb of the internal capsule manifests with isolated contralateral sensory loss, but this is not the most likely etiology of this patient's pure sensory stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the lateral medulla occurs due to occlusion of either the posterior inferior cerebellar artery or branches of the vertebral artery. Infarction of the lateral medulla causes Wallenberg syndrome, which manifests with numbness of the leg and arm contralateral to the lesion. However, patients would also have vestibulocerebellar symptoms, bulbar muscle weakness, and facial paresthesias ipsilateral to the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoperfusion of the basal pons results from occlusion of the penetrating arteries, eventually leading to the development of dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome. Patients present with facial weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and weakness of the hand ipsilateral to the site of the lesion; sensory deficits are absent.

E) CORRECT:

A pure sensory stroke is caused by diminished perfusion of the ventral posterolateral nucleus and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus, which relays sensory information of proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals generally present with unilateral sensory deficits of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus). Chronic hypertension and the resulting lipohyalinosis of small vessels are major risk factors for lacunar infarctions including thalamic strokes.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypoperfusion of the subthalamic nucleus leads to contralateral hemiballismus, not sensory deficits.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (right-sided hemisensory loss) and risk factor for atherosclerosis (hypertension) suggest that he has a pure sensory stroke.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing on the street. On arrival, he is obtunded. His pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 250/120 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head shows an intracerebral hemorrhage involving bilateral thalamic nuclei and the third ventricle. Cortical detection of which of the following types of stimuli is most likely to remain unaffected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Facial fine touch is conveyed via the ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus, the relay center for the trigeminal nerve pathway. The ventral posteromedial nucleus receives afferent input from the trigeminal nucleus and projects to the primary somatosensory cortex. Hence, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect facial fine touch.

B) INCORRECT:

Gustatory information is conveyed via the ventral posteromedial nucleus, the thalamic relay center for taste. The ventral posterior medial nucleus receives afferent input from the trigeminal nucleus and projects to the primary somatosensory cortex. Hence, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect taste.

C) INCORRECT:

Visual information is conveyed via the lateral geniculate body, the thalamic relay center for the optic pathway. The lateral geniculate body receives afferent input from optic nerve via the superior colliculus and projects to the primary visual cortex. Therefore, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect vision.

D) INCORRECT:

Auditory information is conveyed via the medial geniculate nucleus, the thalamic relay center for the auditory pathway. The medial geniculate nucleus receives afferent input from the inferior colliculus and the superior olivary nucleus and projects to the primary auditory cortex. Therefore, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect auditory sensation.

E) CORRECT:

The olfactory bulb is the first central relay station for the olfactory pathway, which processes odor information. It receives afferent input from the olfactory nerve and projects to the primary olfactory cortex. Although the olfactory sensory neurons do not project directly to the thalamus, the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus receives and sends information to the olfactory cortex. Damage to the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus does not impair cortical olfactory detection (which would result in anosmia), but it does impair other olfactory functions, such as olfactory identification or discrimination (which may result in dysosmia).

Olfactory dysfunction is a common finding on neurologic examination in patients with Alzheimer disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Proprioception is conveyed by the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, the relay center for the dorsal columns. The ventral posterolateral nucleus receives afferent input from the gray matter of the spinal cord via the dorsal columns and projects to the primary somatosensory cortex. Therefore, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect proprioception.
questions.hint: With the exception of one pathway, all sensory information pathways are relayed by thalamic neurons before reaching functionally distinct areas of the cortex. The pathway in question projects to the cortical area that is often the first to be affected in patients with Alzheimer disease.

questions.text:
A young man, 18 years of age, presents for follow-up 2 months after undergoing craniotomy for resection of a craniopharyngioma, which was discovered during an evaluation of absent pubertal development and panhypopituitarism. The patient reports feeling well except for intermittent fever as high as 39°C at home and an increased appetite.
His current medications are levothyroxine 112 μg once daily, hydrocortisone 20 mg in the morning and 10 mg in the afternoon, desmopressin nasal spray, and testosterone intramuscular injections.
On examination, the patient’s temperature is 38.8°C, his heart rate is 97 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 129/88 mm Hg, and his BMI is 34.2. His craniotomy scar is well-healed with no erythema, tenderness, or drainage. There is no nuchal rigidity. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Laboratory evaluation is normal other than a sodium level of 146 mEq/liter (reference range, 136–145) and a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.051 μU/mL (0.5–4.7). His free thyroxine level is 1.8 ng/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.8).
During the 2 weeks before this follow-up visit, two sets of blood cultures, a urinalysis and urine culture, analysis of a cerebrospinal-fluid sample, and a chest radiograph were all normal. An MRI of the head reveals the expected postoperative changes.
Which one of the following causes of fever is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A postoperative wound infection would be characterized by abnormalities on inspection, imaging, or culture that are not present in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has panhypopituitarism and appears to be receiving appropriate hormone-replacement therapy: hydrocortisone (a glucocorticoid) for the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and levothyroxine (synthetic thyroid hormone) for the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis. Of note, the thyroid-stimulating hormone level cannot be used to guide levothyroxine dosing in patients with a central (pituitary or hypothalamic) disorder, because the central process interferes with thyroid-stimulating hormone secretion; rather, the free thyroxine level is used to guide levothyroxine dosing. Hence, this patient is not overrepleted, and overrepletion of thyroid hormone cannot explain the fever.

C) INCORRECT:

A drug reaction is unlikely in a patient who is receiving stable doses of their medications and whose fever is intermittent. In nonsensitized individuals receiving a drug for the first time, the onset of fever is highly variable and differs among drug classes, but it most commonly occurs after 7 to 10 days of drug administration and rapidly reverses after discontinuation of the drug.

D) CORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are usually located in the suprasellar area, where they can cause symptoms from mass effect (headaches, visual-field loss), pituitary dysfunction, and hypothalamic dysfunction. Surgical resection may be complicated and sometimes leads to further local destruction.

However, this patient has evidence of hypothalamic dysfunction. He has diabetes insipidus, as he is taking desmopressin and has obesity. In the absence of evidence of infection, the most likely diagnosis is hyperthermia from hypothalamic dysfunction. This is a rare cause of fever — hypothermia is more common — but should be considered when no other cause can be identified in a patient with a known hypothalamic lesion. The patient also has appetite dysregulation, another feature of hypothalamic dysregulation that often results in severe obesity.

Key learning point: The most typical manifestations of anatomical problems of the hypothalamus are change in appetite, change in thirst, and dysregulation of sleep and body temperature.

E) INCORRECT:

Although inadequate glucocorticoid replacement can be associated with fever, the patient’s dosing, blood pressure, and well-being are not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 58-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset numbness on the right side of his body for the past hour. He has a 15-year history of hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide. He is right-handed. On examination, he is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Neurological examination reveals decreased sensation to light pinprick and temperature on the right side of his face and body. Motor strength is 5/5 and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Perfusion of which one of the following brain structures is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A pure sensory stroke is caused by diminished perfusion of the ventral posterolateral nucleus and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus, which relays sensory information of proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals generally present with unilateral sensory deficits of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus). Chronic hypertension and the resulting lipohyalinosis of small vessels are major risk factors for lacunar infarctions including thalamic strokes.

Key learning point: A pure sensory stroke is most commonly caused by lacunar infarction of the ventral posterior thalamus, resulting in contralateral sensory loss without motor deficits.

B) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of one of its blood-supplying vessels, predominantly the anterior cerebral artery (ACA), and middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of the ACA or MCA may result in numbness. However, a stroke typically on the nondominant (usually right) side would manifest with symptoms of contralateral (left-sided) neglect, while infarction of the dominant (usually left) side would manifest with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Diminished perfusion of the lateral medulla occurs due to occlusion of either the posterior inferior cerebellar artery or branches of the vertebral artery. Infarction of the lateral medulla causes Wallenberg syndrome, which manifests with numbness of the leg and arm contralateral to the lesion. However, patients would also have vestibulocerebellar symptoms, bulbar muscle weakness, and facial paresthesias ipsilateral to the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoperfusion of the subthalamic nucleus leads to contralateral hemiballismus, not sensory deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule occurs due to hemorrhage or occlusion of the lenticulostriate arteries, which supply blood to the greater part of the internal capsule. As fibers of the corticospinal tract pass downward through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, infarction of the posterior limb usually leads to a pure motor stroke with hemiparesis of the leg, arm, and face contralateral to the site of the lesion. Rarely, ischemia of the posterior limb of the internal capsule manifests with isolated contralateral sensory loss, but this is not the most likely etiology of this patient's pure sensory stroke.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (right-sided hemisensory loss) and risk factor for atherosclerosis (hypertension) suggest that he has a pure sensory stroke.
